result_equations.equation: vec L = vec r times vec p = I vec omega

explanation: Angular momentum is conserved when no external torque acts on a system. This fundamental conservation law explains phenomena from planetary motion to figure skating spins. Angular momentum equals the cross product of position and momentum vectors, or the product of moment of inertia and angular velocity for rigid bodies.

definitions.definition: Moment of inertia about the rotation axis.
External torque acting on the system.

assumptions: No external torques act on the system (`vec tau_ext = 0`).
The system can be treated as a collection of particles or rigid bodies.
Newton's laws apply to each particle in the system.
Internal forces between particles obey Newton's third law.

derivation.description: Define total angular momentum as sum of angular momenta of all particles.
derivation.equation: vec L = sum_i vec r_i times vec p_i

derivation.description: Take the time derivative of total angular momentum.
derivation.equation: d vec L/dt = sum_i (d/dt(vec r_i times vec p_i))

derivation.description: Apply product rule: first term vanishes since velocity is parallel to momentum.
derivation.equation: d vec L/dt = sum_i (vec v_i times vec p_i + vec r_i times d vec p_i/dt)

derivation.description: Use Newton's second law and recognize that internal forces cancel in pairs.
derivation.equation: d vec L/dt = sum_i vec r_i times vec F_i

derivation.description: The remaining sum equals the net external torque on the system.
If external torque is zero, angular momentum is conserved.
derivation.equation: If vec tau_ext = 0, then d vec L/dt = 0 => vec L = const
